In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful
Introduction:
Indeed, praise is due to Allah, we praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and from the bad consequences of our deeds. He whom Allah guides, no one can misguide, and he whom He misguides, no one can guide. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, without partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.
Our author is Imam Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya. He was born in an era where sciences flourished and grew up in a house of knowledge and virtue. He took knowledge from the great scholars of his time. He took from his father the science of (Inheritance), and heard (Hadith) from the meteor of his age Al-Nabulsi, Judge Taqi al-Din, Ismail bin Maktum, and Fatima bint Jawhar. He took (Arabic) from Abu al-Fath al-Ba'li and Majd al-Din al-Tunisi. He received Usul and Fiqh from Sheikh Safi al-Din al-Hindi and Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah. Ibn Taymiyyah is considered the first guide for Ibn al-Qayyim and his role model; he was greatly influenced by him and was persecuted for his sake. And Sheikh Ismail al-Harrani.
Imam Ibn al-Qayyim is well-known, and whoever wants to refer to his biography, his works, and what our scholars wrote about him, should refer to these references:

text:
Book of Parables by the Scholar Ibn al-Qayyim
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon the best of creation, Muhammad, and his family and companions all.
Our Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, said: There are parables in the Quran, and the parables (1) of the Quran are understood only by the knowledgeable. They are the likeness (2) of something to something in its ruling, bringing the reasonable closer to the sensible, or one of the two sensibles to the other, and considering one by the other. Like His saying, Exalted is He, regarding the hypocrites: (Their example is that of one who kindled a fire, but when it illuminated what was around him, Allah took away their light and left them in darkness [so] they could not see. Deaf, dumb and blind - so they will not return [to the right path]. Or [it is] like a rainstorm from the sky within which is darkness, thunder and lightning. They put their fingers in their ears against the thunderclaps in dread of death. But Allah is encompassing of the disbelievers) [to His saying] (Indeed, Allah is over all things competent) (3). So He struck two parables for the hypocrites according to their condition: a fire parable (4) and a water parable, because of what water and fire (5) contain of illumination, brightness, and life. For fire is the substance of light and water is the substance of life. Allah, Glory be to Him, made the revelation sent down from the sky contain the life of hearts and their illumination. Therefore, He called it Spirit and Light (6), and made its acceptors alive in the light, and those who did not raise a head to it dead in darkness.
He informed about the condition of the hypocrites regarding their share of the revelation, that they are like one who kindled a fire to light up for him and to benefit from it. This is because they entered into Islam, so they sought light by it and benefited from it.

2. In M, A (It is only likening).
3. Surah Al-Baqarah: 17 - 20.
4. Addition from M, A.
5. Referring to the verse (And thus We have revealed to you an inspiration of Our command...) Al-Shura 52 / 53.
6. The Spirit refers to the Quran and the Light is the Quranic revelation. See Al-Shura: 52. (*)

Likening the disbelievers to rain accompanied by darkness, thunder, and lightning. They believed in it and mixed with the Muslims. But because their companionship (7) did not have a substance from their hearts of the light of Islam, it disappeared from them and Allah took away their light. He did not say their fire, for fire contains illumination and burning; so Allah took away the illumination in it and left upon them the burning in it, and left them in darknesses not seeing. This is the condition of one who saw then became blind, knew then denied, and entered Islam then separated from it with his heart, not returning to it. That is why He said (8): (So they will not return).
Then He mentioned their condition regarding the water parable, so He likened them to people in a rainstorm, which is the rain pouring down, meaning descending from the sky (9), in which are darknesses, thunder, and lightning. Because of the weakness of their insights and minds, the deterrents of the Quran, its threats, intimidations, commands, prohibitions, and discourse which resembles thunderbolts became severe upon them. So their condition is like the condition of one struck by rain in which is darkness, thunder, and lightning. Due to his weakness and fear (10), he put his two fingers in his ears fearing a thunderbolt striking him.
We and others have witnessed many of the effeminate disciples of the Jahmiyyah (11) and innovators. When they hear something of the verses of Attributes and Hadiths of Attributes contrary to their innovation, you see them turning away from them as if they were frightened donkeys fleeing from a lion. Their effeminate one says: Close this door for us, and read something other than this. You see their hearts turning away while they bolt, due to the heaviness of knowing the Lord, Glory be to Him and Exalted, and His names and attributes on their minds and hearts. Likewise, the polytheists, despite their varying polytheism, if Tawhid (monotheism) is isolated for them and its texts (12) invalidating...

...their polytheism, which is the water by which life exists, are recited to them, their hearts shrink and it becomes heavy (13) on them. If they found a way to plug their ears, they would do so. Likewise (14), we find the enemies of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, finding that very heavy on them, so their hearts denied it. All this is apparent resemblance and verified likeness from their brothers among the hypocrites in the parable Allah struck for them with water. For when their hearts were similar, their deeds were similar (15).

Chapter: He, Glory be to Him, mentioned the two parables, water and fire, in Surah Al-Ra'd, but regarding the believers. He said, Exalted is He: (He sends down from the sky, rain, and valleys flow according to their capacity, and the torrent carries a rising foam. And from that [ore] which they heat in the fire, desiring ornaments or utensils, is a foam like it. Thus Allah presents [the example of]...) (16). He likened the revelation He sent down for the life of hearts, hearing, and sight to the water He sent down for the life of the earth with vegetation. He likened hearts to valleys (17). So a big heart holds great knowledge like a big valley holds much water, and a small heart holds according to its size like the small valley. So valleys flowed according to their capacity, and hearts carried guidance and knowledge according to their capacity. Just as the torrent, when it mixes with the earth and passes over it, carries (18) scum and foam, so does guidance and knowledge when it mixes with hearts, it stirs up what is in them of desires and doubts to uproot and remove them. Just as medicine, at the time of drinking it, stirs up the mixtures from the body, so the drinker is distressed (19) by it. It is from the completeness of the medicine's benefit that it stirred them up to remove them, for it does not coexist or dwell with them. Thus (Allah presents Truth and Falsehood). Then He mentioned the fire parable...

...so He said: (And from that [ore] which they heat in the fire, desiring ornaments or utensils, is a foam like it) (20). It is the impurity that comes out when casting gold, silver, copper, and iron (21). The fire brings it out, distinguishes it, and separates it from the substance that is benefited from, so it is thrown away, cast off, and goes as scum. Similarly, desires and doubts are thrown away by the believer's heart, cast off, and expelled, just as the torrent and fire cast off that foam, scum, and impurity. And the clear water settles in the bottom of the valley, from which people drink (22), irrigate, and water their livestock. Likewise, the pure, sincere faith settles in the bottom of the heart and its root, which benefits its owner and by which others benefit (23). And whoever does not understand these two parables and does not ponder them and know what is intended by them is not of their people, and Allah is the Grantor of success.

Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He: (The example of [this] worldly life is but like rain which We have sent down from the sky that the plants of the earth absorb - those from which men and livestock eat - until, when the earth has taken on its adornment and is beautified and its people assume that they have capability over it, there comes to it Our command by night or by day, and We make it as a harvest, as if it had not flourished yesterday. Thus do We explain in detail the signs for a people who give thought) (24). He, Glory be to Him, likened the worldly life in that it beautifies itself in the eye of the beholder, so it pleases him with its adornment and amazes him (25), so he inclines towards it and desires it, being deceived by it. Until, when he thinks he is its owner, capable over it, it is snatched away suddenly (26) when he is most in need of it, and a barrier is placed between him and it. So He likened it...

...to the land upon which rain descends, so it becomes grassy, its vegetation improves, and its view pleases the beholder, so he is deceived by it and thinks he is capable over it, owning it. Then the command of Allah comes to it, and calamity overtakes its vegetation suddenly, so it becomes as if it did not exist before. Thus his hope is dashed and his hands become empty of it. Such (27) is the condition of the world and the one trusting in it, equally. This is the most eloquent simile and analogy. Since the world is prone to these calamities and Paradise is safe from them, Allah Exalted said: (And Allah invites to the Home of Peace) (28). He named it here the Home of Peace because of its safety from these calamities He mentioned in the world. So He generalized the invitation to it and specified guidance for whom He willed; that is His justice and this is His grace (29).

Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He: (The example of the two parties is like the blind and deaf, and the seeing and hearing. Are they equal in comparison? Then, will you not remember?) (30). He, Glory be to Him and Exalted, mentioned the disbelievers and described them as not being able to hear and not seeing. Then He mentioned the believers and described them with faith, righteous deeds, and submission to their Lord. So He described them with servitude of the apparent and the hidden. He made one of the two parties like the blind and deaf, since his heart was blind to seeing the truth, deaf to hearing it. So he was likened (31) to one whose sight is blind to seeing the truest of things (32) and whose hearing is deaf to hearing sounds. And the other party is seeing of heart, hearing, like the seeing of eye and hearing of ear. The verse contained two analogies and two representations for the two parties. Then He denied equality between the two parties by His saying (Are they equal in comparison) (33).

Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He: (The example of those who take allies other than Allah is like that of the spider) (34). So He mentioned, Glory be to Him, that they are weak and that those they took as allies...

...are weaker than them. So they, in their weakness and what they intended by taking allies, are like the spider that took a house, which is the frailest of houses and the weakest (35). Under this parable is that these polytheists are at their weakest when they took allies other than Allah. They did not gain from those they took as allies except weakness, as the Almighty said: (And they have taken gods besides Allah that they might be for them a source of honor. No! Those "gods" will deny their worship of them and will be against them opponents) (36). And the Almighty said: (And they have taken gods besides Allah that perhaps they would be helped. They are not able to help them, and they [themselves] are for them soldiers in attendance) (37). And He said after mentioning the destruction of the polytheist nations: (And We did not wrong them, but they wronged themselves. And they were not availed at all by their gods which they invoked other than Allah when there came the command of your Lord. And they did not increase them in anything but ruin) (38). These are four places in the Quran indicating that whoever takes an ally other than Allah to be strengthened by, to increase by, and to be helped by, will not obtain by it except the opposite of his intention. And in the Quran there is more than that. This is one of the best parables and most indicative of the futility of polytheism, the loss of its owner, and his obtaining the opposite of his intention.
If it is said: They (39) know that the frailest of houses is the spider's house, so how did He negate their knowledge of that by His saying: (if they only knew). The answer is that He, Glory be to Him, did not negate (40) from them their knowledge of the frailty of the spider's house, but He negated their knowledge that their taking allies other than Him is like the spider taking a house. If they knew that, they would not have done it. But they thought that their taking allies other than Him would benefit them with honor and strength, so the matter was contrary to what they thought (41).

Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He: (But those who disbelieved - their deeds are like a mirage in a lowland which a thirsty one thinks is water until, when he comes to it, he finds it is nothing but finds Allah before Him, and He will pay him in full his due; and Allah is swift in account. Or [they are] like darknesses within an unfathomable sea which is covered by waves, upon which are waves, over which are clouds - darknesses, some of them upon others. When one puts out his hand [therein], he can hardly see it. And he to whom Allah has not granted light - for him there is no light) (42).
He, Glory be to Him, mentioned two parables for the disbelievers: a parable of a mirage and a parable of accumulated darknesses. That is because those turning away from guidance and truth are of two types. One of them thinks he is on something (right), then it becomes clear to him upon the uncovering of realities the opposite of what he thought. This is the condition of the people of ignorance and people of innovations and desires who think they are on guidance and knowledge. When realities are uncovered, it becomes clear to them that they were not on anything, and that their beliefs (43) and deeds (44) which were based on them were like a mirage seen in the eyes (45) of beholders as water, yet has no reality. Likewise are the deeds (46) that are for other than Allah Almighty and not on His command; the doer thinks them beneficial to him (47) while they are not so. These are the deeds about which Allah Almighty said: (And We will regard what they have done of deeds and make them as scattered dust (48)). Ponder how Allah, Glory be to Him, placed the mirage in a 'Qi'ah' (lowland), which is the empty land devoid of buildings, trees...

43. He means the Jahmiyyah.
44. His saying (were based on them...) 'them' pronoun refers to the people of ignorance and innovations who think they are on guidance and light.

46. Deeds that are not conforming to Allah's commands and their doer thinks they are beneficial, like the deeds of people of innovations and desires; due to their ignorance they think they are beneficial while in reality there is no good in them.

...and plants (49) and people. So the place of the mirage is a desolate land with nothing (50) in it. The mirage has no reality, and that corresponds to their deeds and hearts which became devoid of faith and guidance. Ponder what is under His saying (Which a thirsty one thinks is water). The thirsty one (51) is he whose thirst has become intense, so he saw the mirage and thought it was water, so he followed it but found it nothing; rather it betrayed him when he was most in need of it. Likewise, these people, because their deeds were not in obedience to the Messengers (52), peace be upon them, and were for other than Allah, they were made like a mirage. It was raised for them when they were most thirsty for it (53), but they found nothing and found Allah, Glory be to Him (54), then. So He recompensed them for their deeds and paid them their account in full.
In the Sahih from the Hadith of Abu Saeed Al-Khudri (55), may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, in the Hadith of the Manifestation on the Day of Resurrection: (Then Hell will be brought, displayed as if it were a mirage. It will be said to the Jews: What did you use to worship? They will say: We used to worship Ezra, the son of Allah. It will be said: You lied, Allah has no wife or son. So what do you want? They will say: We want You to give us drink. It will be said: Drink, and they will fall into Hell. Then it will be said to the Christians: What did you use to worship? They will say: We used to worship the Messiah, the son of Allah. It will be said: You lied, Allah had no wife or son. So what do you want? They will say: That You give us drink. It will be said to them: Drink, and they will fall. And he mentioned the Hadith (56)).
This is the condition of every owner of falsehood; his falsehood betrays him when he is most in need of it. For falsehood has no reality, and it is like its name, false (Batil). If the belief is not conforming nor true, its object is false. These are two parables containing two analogies of the reverse analogy, which is negating the ruling due to negating its cause and reason. ...and tongue. With this, he is helpless, unable to do anything at all. And with this, wherever you send him, he brings you no good nor fulfills a need for you. And Allah, Glory be to Him, is Living, Capable, Speaking, commanding justice, and He is on a straight path. This is a description of Him with the utmost perfection and praise. For His commanding justice, which is the truth, implies that He, Glory be to Him, is knowing of it, teaching it, pleased with it, commanding His servants with it, loving its people, not commanding other than it; rather He is exalted above its opposite which is injustice, oppression, foolishness, and falsehood. Indeed, His command and law are all justice. The people of justice are His allies and loved ones, and they are the ones neighboring Him (99) in it on His right on pulpits of light.
His commanding justice includes the legislative religious command and the predestined universal command; both are justice with no injustice in them whatsoever, as in the Sahih Hadith: (O Allah, I am Your servant, son of Your servant, son of Your maidservant, my forelock is in Your hand, Your command over me is forever executed and Your decree over me is just) (100). His decree is His universal command, for His command when He wills a thing is only to say to it, "Be," and it is. So He does not command with truth and justice (101). And His decree and destiny established by Him are truth and justice, even if in the decreed and destined there is what is injustice and oppression. For the decree (102) is other than the decreed, and the destiny is other than the destined.
Then He informed, Glory be to Him, (that He is on a straight path). This corresponds to the saying of Shu'aib (103), peace be upon him: (Indeed, I have relied upon Allah, my Lord and your Lord. There is no creature but that He holds its forelock. Indeed, my Lord is on a path [that is] straight) (104). His saying: (There is no creature but that He holds its forelock) corresponds to his saying: (my forelock is in Your hand). And His saying: (Indeed, my Lord is on a path [that is] straight) corresponds to his saying (Your decree over me is just). The first is His sovereignty and the second is His praise. And He, Glory be to Him, to Him belongs sovereignty and to Him belongs praise. His being, Glory be to Him, on a straight path implies that He does not say except the truth, and does not command except with justice, and does not do except what is interest, wisdom, and justice...

Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He, in likening those who turned away from His speech and pondering it: (Then what is [the matter] with them that they are turning away from the reminder? As if they were frightened donkeys. Fleeing from a lion?) (119). He likened them in their turning away and aversion from the Quran to donkeys that saw the lion and archers so they fled from it. This is of the wondrous representation (120). For the people, out of their ignorance of what Allah, Glory be to Him, sent His Messenger, peace be upon him, with, are like donkeys; they do not understand anything. When they hear the voice of the lion or the archer, they flee from it with intense aversion. This is the utmost blame for these, for they fled from the guidance in which is their happiness and life like the fleeing of donkeys from what destroys and hamstrings them.
Under 'Mustanfira' (frightened/alerted) is a meaning more eloquent than 'Nafira' (fleeing). For due to the intensity of their aversion, some of them alerted others and incited them to flee. Whoever read it with Fatha on the Fa' (Mustanfara) (122), the meaning is: That the lion alerted them and drove them to flee by his might and intensity (123).

From its greed is that it does not walk except with its snout on the ground sniffing and smelling out of greed and covetousness. It constantly smells its anus unlike other parts. If you throw a stone at it, it returns to it to bite it out of excessive gluttony. It is one of the most humiliated animals, most bearing of insult, most pleased with filth; rotting carcasses are more beloved to it than fresh meat, and filth is more beloved to it than sweets. If it gets hold of a carcass sufficient for a hundred dogs, it does not leave a dog (130) to partake with it of it anything except it growls at it and overpowers it (131) due to its greed, stinginess, and evil. text: ...Allah and the Hereafter despite his abundant knowledge, to the dog in its panting (133) is a wondrous secret. It is that he whose condition is what Allah mentioned of his detachment from His signs and following his desire, was only due to the intensity of his panting (grief/anxiety) for the world because of the severance of his heart from Allah and the Hereafter; so he is intensely panting for it. His panting corresponds to the constant panting of the dog in the state of its disturbance and leaving. 'Lahf' (grief/anxiety) and 'Lahth' (panting) are siblings and brothers in word and meaning. Ibn Jurayj said: (134) (The dog has a severed heart, it has no heart. If you chase him he pants or if you leave him he pants. So he is like the one who leaves guidance, he has no heart, his heart is only severed). I said: His intent by the severance of his heart is that he has no heart to carry him to patience and leaving panting. Likewise, he who detached from Allah's signs, there remained with him no heart to carry him to patience from the world and leaving panting for it. This one pants for the world due to lack of patience for it, and that one pants due to lack of patience for water. For the dog is one of the animals with least patience for water. If it gets thirsty, it eats the damp earth from thirst, even if it had patience for hunger (135). In any case, it is one of the animals most panting; it pants standing, sitting, walking, and stopping. That is due to the intensity of its greed; the heat of greed in its liver necessitates for it constant panting. Thus is the likened one; the intensity (136) of the heat of desire in his heart necessitates for him constant panting (137). If you load upon him with admonition and advice, he pants, and if you leave him and do not admonish him, he pants. Mujahid said (138): And that is the example of the one who was given the Book and did not work by it. Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He: (O you who have believed, avoid much [negative] assumption. Indeed, some assumption is sin. And do not spy or backbite each other. Would one of you like to eat the flesh of his brother when dead? You would detest it. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is Accepting of repentance and Merciful) (175). This is of the best representative analogy. For He likened tearing the honor of (the brother to tearing his flesh. And since the backbiter tears the honor) of his brother in his absence, he was like one cutting his flesh in the state of the absence of his spirit from him by death. Since the backbited is unable to defend himself by being absent from his blame, he was like the dead whose flesh is cut and cannot defend himself. Since the requirement of brotherhood is mercy, connection, and support, and the backbiter attached to it the opposite of its requirement, of blame, faulting, and defamation, that was like (176) his cutting the flesh of his brother. Brotherhood requires preserving him, protecting him, and defending him. Since the backbiter enjoys (177) his backbiting and blame, finding it sweet, he was likened to eating his brother's flesh after cutting it. Since the backbiter loves that, admiring it, he was likened to one who loves eating his brother's flesh dead. His love for that is an amount added to merely eating it, just as eating it is an amount added to tearing it. Ponder this simile and representation, the goodness of its location, and the correspondence of the reasonable in it to the sensible. Ponder His informing about them hating eating the flesh of the brother dead, and describing them with that at the end of the verse, and denying upon them at its beginning that...

He, Glory be to Him, likened their deeds in their futility and going to waste like scattered dust - because they are on other than a foundation of faith and beneficence, and being for other than Allah Almighty and not on His command - to ashes blown by the stormy wind. Its owner is unable to [keep] anything of it at the time of his intense need for it. Therefore, they are unable to keep from what they have earned a thing; they are unable on the Day of Resurrection to keep anything of what they earned of their deeds. They do not see for them (180) a trace of reward or beneficial utility. For Allah does not accept of deeds except what was purely for His Face, conforming to His law. Deeds are four: one accepted and three rejected. The accepted: The pure and correct. The pure is to be for Allah not other than Him, and the correct is to be of what He legislated on the tongue of His Messenger, peace be upon him. The three rejected: What opposed that.
In likening them to ashes is a wondrous secret. That is due to the resemblance between their deeds and ashes in fire burning and removing the origin of this and that. So the deeds that were for other than Allah Almighty and not on His wish were food for the Fire, and by them the Fire is kindled upon their owners. Allah creates for them from their false deeds fire and torment, just as He creates for the people of deeds conforming to His command (181)...

He said: I do not know for it a settlement in the earth nor an ascent in the sky, except that it sticks to the neck of its owner until he meets with it on the Day of Resurrection) (220). His saying 'ujtuthat' means uprooted from upon the earth.
Then He, Glory be to Him, informed about His judgment and justice regarding the two parties, the owners of good words and bad words. He informed that He keeps firm those who believe, with the firm word, when they are most in need of it in the world and the Hereafter, and that He sends astray the wrongdoers, who are the polytheists, from the firm word. So He sent these astray by His justice for their wrongdoing, and kept the believers firm by His grace for their faith.
Under His saying: (Allah keeps firm those who believe, with the firm word, in worldly life and in the Hereafter) is a great treasure. Whoever finds it, suspects it (221) [values it], improves its extraction and acquisition (222), and spends from it has gained, and whoever is deprived of it has been deprived. That is because the servant is not independent of Allah's keeping firm for the blink of an eye. If He does not keep him firm, the sky of his faith and its earth will vanish from their places. The Almighty said to the most honored of His creation to Him, His servant and Messenger, peace be upon him: (And if We had not strengthened you, you would have almost inclined to them a little) (223). And the Almighty said: ([Remember] when your Lord inspired to the angels, "I am with you, so strengthen those who have believed) (224). In the two Sahihs from the Hadith of Al-Bajali he said: (And he asks for them and strengthens them) (225). And the Almighty said to His Messenger, peace be upon him: (And each [story] We relate to you from the news of the messengers is that by which We make firm your heart) (226).

text: So all creation are two types: successful by strengthening, and forsaken by leaving strengthening. The substance of strengthening, its origin and source, is from the firm word and doing what the servant is commanded. In both, Allah strengthens His servant. So whatever is firmer in saying and better in deed is greater in strengthening. The Almighty said: (But if they had done what they were instructed, it would have been better for them and a firmer position [for them] in faith) (227). So the firmest people in heart are the firmest in saying. The firm saying is the saying of truth and honesty, and it is the opposite of the false saying, lying. So saying is of two types: firm having reality, and false having no reality. The firmest saying is the word of Tawhid and its implications; it is the greatest thing by which Allah strengthens His servants in the world and the Hereafter. Therefore, you see the truthful as the firmest of people and bravest in heart, and the liar as the most humiliated of people, most malicious, most twisting, and least firm (228). People of insight know the truthfulness of the truthful from the firmness of his heart at the time of testing, his courage and dignity, and know (229) the lie of the liar by the opposite of that. This is not hidden except to one of weak insight. Some were asked about speech he heard from a speaker, so he said: By Allah, I understood nothing from it except that I heard for his speech an assault that is not the assault of a falsifier. So the servant is not granted a gift better than the gift of the firm word). The people of the firm word find its fruit when they are most in need of it in their graves and on the day of their return. text: ...parable and ponder it with true pondering, for it cuts off the resources (251) of Shirk from his heart. That is because the worshipped, its lowest degree is to be able to create what benefits its worshipper and execute what harms him. And the gods which the polytheists worship besides Allah will never (252) be able to create a fly (253), even if they all gathered to create it, let alone what is bigger than it. Nor are they able to avenge against the fly if it steals from them something of what is on them of perfume and the like, to recover it from it. They are neither capable of creating the fly, which is one of the weakest animals, nor of avenging against it and recovering what it stole from them. There is nothing more incapable than these gods nor weaker than them. So how can a rational person approve of worshipping them besides Allah Almighty? This parable is of the most eloquent of what Allah Glory be to Him sent down regarding the invalidity of Shirk and attributing ignorance to its people and ugliness to their minds, and testifying that the devils tamper (254) with them greater than the tampering of boys with a ball. Where they gave divinity, of whose necessary implications are capability over all possibilities, encompassing all information, independence from all creatures, and that one resorts (255) to the Lord in all needs, relieving distresses, aiding the grieving, and answering prayers; so they gave it to images and statues for whom capability over the creatures of the True God (256), and the lowest, smallest, and most despicable of them, is impossible, even if they gathered for that and cooperated on it. So when it is the day of fulfilling deeds and obtaining rewards, the worker finds (290) his work has been struck by what struck the owner of this garden. His regret then is more severe than the regret of this one over his garden. This is a parable Allah, Glory be to Him, struck for regret over the loss of blessing at the time of intense need for it, with the greatness of its value and benefit. He from whom it went away has been struck by old age and weakness, so he is most in need of his blessing. So his need for his blessing then is most intense due to his weakness and the weakness of his offspring. ...its hardness from faith, sincerity, (and beneficence) (298) is in the position of the stone. And the deed which (299) is for other than Allah is in the position of dust that is on that stone. The strength of what is under it and its solidity prevent it from firmness and growth (300) when the heavy rain falls. So it has no substance connected to what accepts water and grows herbage. Likewise, the heart of the show-off has no firmness at the heavy rain of command, prohibition, decree, and destiny. If the heavy rain of revelation descends upon it, that little dust which was on it is uncovered, and what is under it appears as a bare stone with no plant in it. This is a parable Allah, Glory be to Him, struck for the deed of the show-off and his spending; he is unable on the Day of Resurrection to [obtain] reward for any of it when he is most in need of it. And with Allah is success (301).

Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He: (Indeed, those who disbelieve - never will their wealth or their children avail them against Allah at all. And those are the companions of the Fire - they will abide therein eternally. The example of what they spend in this worldly life is like that of a wind containing frost which strikes the harvest of a people who have wronged themselves and destroys it. And Allah has not wronged them, but they wrong themselves (302)). This is a parable Allah Almighty struck for whoever spent his wealth in other than His obedience and pleasure. He, Glory be to Him, likened what these spend of their wealth in generosities, prides, gaining praise and good mention, not seeking (303) by it the Face of Allah, and what they spend to hinder from the way of Allah and following His messengers, peace be upon them, to the crop which its owner planted hoping for its benefit and good, then a wind of very intense cold struck it, its cold burning what it passes over of crops and fruits, so it destroyed that crop and dried it up.

They differed regarding 'Al-Sirr'. It was said: Intense cold (304). And it was said: Fire (305), said by Ibn Abbas. Al-Anbari said (306): Fire was described as Sirr only because of its crackling sound (Tasriya) when flaming. And it was said: Al-Sirr (307) is the sound that accompanies the wind from the intensity of its blowing (308). The three opinions are correlative; it is intense cold burning with its dryness for the harvest as fire burns, and in it is intense sound. In His saying: (which strikes the harvest of a people who have wronged themselves) is an alert that the cause of its striking their harvest is their wrong; it is what empowered the mentioned wind against them until it destroyed their crop and dried it up. So their wrong is the wind that destroyed their deeds and expenses and ruined them.

Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He: (Allah presents an example: a man in whom are partners differing with each other and a man handed over to a man - are they equal in comparison? Praise be to Allah! But most of them do not know) (309). This is a parable Allah, Glory be to Him, struck for the polytheist and the monotheist. The polytheist is in the position of a slave owned by a group (310) sharing in his service; he cannot please them all. The monotheist, since he worships Allah alone, his example is like the example of a slave of one man, who has submitted to him, knew his purposes (and knew the way) (311) to his pleasure. So he is at rest from the quarreling of partners over him; rather he is safe for his owner without dispute over him, with his owner's kindness to him, his mercy for him, his compassion for him, his beneficence to him, and his taking care of his interests (312). So do these two slaves equal? This...

Chapter: And among them is His saying, Exalted is He: (Allah presents an example of those who disbelieved: the wife of Noah and the wife of Lot. They were under two of Our righteous servants but betrayed them, so those prophets did not avail them from Allah at all, and it was said, "Enter the Fire with those who enter." And Allah presents an example of those who believed: the wife of Pharaoh, when she said, "My Lord, build for me near You a house in Paradise and save me from Pharaoh and his deeds and save me from the wrongdoing people." And [the example of] Mary, the daughter of Imran, who guarded her chastity, so We blew into [her garment] through Our angel, and she believed in the words of her Lord and His scriptures and was of the devoutly obedient) (314). These verses included three parables: A parable for the disbeliever (315) and two parables for the believers.
The parable of disbelievers implies that the disbeliever is blamed for his disbelief and enmity to Allah Almighty, His Messenger peace be upon him, and His allies. And that what was between him and the believers of bond of lineage or link of in-law relationship or cause of the causes of connection (316) does not benefit him with his disbelief. For relationships (all) (317) are cut off on the Day of Resurrection except what was of them connected to Allah alone at the hands (318) of His messengers, peace be upon them. If the link of kinship, in-law relationship, and marriage benefited with lack of faith, the link (319) which was between Noah and Lot (320), peace be upon them, and their two wives would have benefited. Since they did not avail them from Allah at all...

...and it was said to them: Enter the Fire with those who enter, the verse then cut off the hope of one who committed disobedience to Allah Almighty and opposed His command, and hoped that the righteousness of another from a relative or stranger would benefit him, even if there was the strongest connection between them in the world. For there is no connection above the connection of prophethood, fatherhood, and marriage. Noah, peace be upon him, did not avail his son, nor Abraham, peace be upon him, his father, nor Noah and Lot, peace be upon them, their wives from Allah at all. Allah Almighty said: (Never will your relatives or your children benefit you; the Day of Resurrection He will judge between you) (321). And the Almighty said: ([It will be] a Day when no soul shall possess for [another] soul any power, and the command, that Day, is [entirely] with Allah) (322). And the Almighty said: (And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all) (323). And the Almighty said: (And fear a Day when no father will avail his son, nor will a child avail his father at all) (324). All this is a denial of the false hopes of the polytheists that those they attached themselves to besides Allah of kinship, in-law relationship, marriage, or companionship would benefit them on the Day of Resurrection or protect them from the punishment of Allah Almighty or intercede for them with Allah Almighty. This is the origin of the misguidance of the children of Adam and their polytheism, and it is the Shirk which Allah does not forgive. It is what Allah Almighty sent all His messengers, peace be upon them, and revealed all His books to invalidate and to fight its people and oppose them.

Chapter: As for the two parables which are for the believers, one of them is the wife of Pharaoh (325). The face of the parable: That the connection of the believer with the disbeliever does not harm him at all if he separates from him in his disbelief and deed. The disobedience of the sinner does not harm the obedient at all in the Hereafter, even if he is harmed by it in the world due to the punishment that befalls the people of earth if they waste the command of Allah Almighty, so it comes generally. So it did not harm...

...Pharaoh's wife her connection to him while he is one of the most disbelieving of disbelievers. And their connection to them did not benefit the wife of Noah and Lot, while they were messengers of the Lord of the Worlds.
The second parable for believers: Mary who has no husband, neither believer nor disbeliever. So He mentioned three categories of women: The disbelieving woman who has a link to the righteous man, the righteous woman who has a link to the disbelieving man, and the single woman who has no link between her and anyone. The first, her link and cause do not benefit her; the second, her link and cause do not harm her; and the third, the lack of link does not harm her at all (326).
Then in these parables there are wondrous secrets that suit the context of the Surah. For it was driven in mentioning the wives of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and warning them against backing each other against him, and that if they do not obey Allah and His Messenger, peace be upon him, and desire the Hereafter, their connection to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, will not benefit them as their connection to them did not benefit the wife of Noah and Lot. For this reason (327) He struck for them in this Surah the example of the connection of marriage, not kinship. Yahya bin Salam (328) said: (Allah struck the first parable warning Aisha (329) and Hafsa (330), then He struck for them the second parable inciting them to hold fast to obedience. And in striking the parable for the believers (with Mary) (331) there is also another consideration, which is that it did not harm her with Allah at all the slander of the enemies of Allah Almighty, the Jews, (of her) (332) and their attributing her and her son to what Allah absolved them from, despite her being the Great Siddiqa chosen over the women of the worlds. So it does not harm...

...the righteous man, the slander (333) of the wicked and dissolute against him. In this is a consolation for Aisha (334), Mother of the Believers, if the Surah was revealed after the incident of Al-Ifk, and settling herself on what the liars said about her if it was before it, as in the representation (335) by the wife of Noah and Lot is a warning to her and Hafsa regarding what they relied upon in the right of the Prophet, peace be upon him. So these parables contained warning to them, frightening, inciting them to obedience and Tawhid, consolation, and settling the self for whoever was harmed among them and lied against. The secrets of revelation are above this and more majestic, especially the secrets of parables which are understood only by the knowledgeable.
